title: Toni Minichiello throws hat in ring to become new boss of British athletics
text:

Toni Minichiello, who coached Jess Ennis-Hill to Olympic gold and multiple world titles, has thrown his hat into the ring to become the next boss of British Athletics.

The move follows Neil Black confirming that he will quit at the end of the month, leaving Great Britain without a leader nine months out from the Tokyo Olympics.

Twenty four hours after saying he would take his time to make a decision Black, performance director of UK Athletics, fell on his sword.

Minichiello confirmed to Mirror Sport: "If I was approached about the job, I's be happy to have a conversation."

Black is just back from Doha where, for all the glory of Dina Asher-Smith and Katarina Johnson-Thompson, Britain fell two short of the ‘minimum’ seven-goal tally set for them by UK Sport. The target set for them in Tokyo is between eight and 10.

More damaging for him was his continued support for Alberto Salazar, who was last week handed a four-year ban for multiple coaching violations.

(Image: Getty)

(Image: British Athletics via Getty Imag)

UK Athletics conducted a review in 2015 and said there was "no concern" about Salazar's link with Mo Farah, Britain’s leading athlete.

Black, who took charge in 2013, referred to Salazar as a “genius” and “one of the best people to work with that I have ever come across”

(Image: Getty)

On Sunday night he admitted he had been “shocked” by the verdict on Salazar. Less than 72 hours later he has served notice.

His final job is to accompany Farah to Chicago where he defends his marathon title this weekend.
description: The man who coached Jess Ennis-Hill to Olympic and world titles reveals interest in role Neil Black will vacate at end of month
